text: 19th December 2016Level 42 bottleshare, Santa is flying past below! Clear deep amber beer, bubbly pale cream colour head. Tart fruits on the snout. Smooth palate, semi dry with modest fine carbonation. Some sour red/brown tart fruits and tangy red wine. Sweetish dessert wine changes the direction. Very mild brett. Tartish fruity finish. Doubt this tart turn was intended but it does no harm at all here.

Bottle at level 42, cheers Kenny. It pour some deep reddish - brown with a small beige head. The aroma is rich, sweet, tangy, sweet vinous character, booze, fruit cake, oak and jammy fruits. The taste is crisp, tart, tangy, vinous, jammy berry, cranberry, salty, grape skin, lemon sherbet, treacle and oak. Full body, fine carbonation and oil mouth - feel. Slick and very fruity. Good fun and rather tasty overall.

December 2016 - Bottle share at 1 Canada Square. Thanks Ken! As Schneider Weisse Tap X Eisbock Barrique 2015, 12%. Dark brown, translucent, foamy tan head leaves dotted lacing. Aroma is varnish, oaky, some light vinegar. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is rich with some harsh alcohol and woody notes, red wine, almost a little acidic it seemed to me. A slow drinker but tasty. Could divide opinion due to some harsh flavours. (3.7)

38cl bottle shared in CW. Many thanks to Ken for this one. It pours a clean copper color with a minimal bubble off white head. Aroma is tart sour with notes of macerated red berries and tart cherries, almonds, wood and vanilla. Taste has more acidic tart vinegar notes, red berries, tasty cherries, vanilla, bourbon and wood. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, very tasty although unlikely to be intended this way

Bottle shared in London - thanks to Kenny. Pours clear golden-brown with a slight, creamy topping. Tangy berries in the nose, wood, citrus peel, faint toffee. Medium sweet flavour with light oxidation, brown bread, some acetic notes, alcohol, brown sugar. Medium to full bodied, oily, with minimal carbonation. Warming finish with more berry tang, light earth, wood, booze, a little citric bite. Fun one.

Bottle shared on Level 42 19/12/2016. Many thanks to Kenny for this one. A reddy amber coloured pour with a off white head. Aroma is sour, brown sugars vinegar, red fruit, cake. Flavour is composed of seeet and sour, madeira cake, plum, port, red grape. Oud Brun. Palate is medium sweet sour, lowish carbonation, sticky.. I like it

Bottle split at L42 Xmas mash ooooop, thanks to Kenny Kenny, 19/12/16.
Rich mahogany brown with a decent beige cap.
Nose is tangy dark fruits, fruit loaf, spice, fruit balsams, spice, toffee, wine barrel.
Taste comprises tarte fruit, toffee, funk, barnyard, earthy fruits, red wine barrel, red grape must, dry rot.
Medium + body, fine carboantion, drying close.
Solid stuff ... more a sour red to me than an eisbock in character mind!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: And so it came to pass that six like minded people met on the 20th day of November in the year of 2016: those six people shared twenty five fine beers. This is one of those twenty five. Two 330ml bottles of this, so we all got a decent amount. I am no Eisbock expert, but this was the cloudiest, murkiest and dirtiest one I have seen so far. Obviously the barrel ageing had more than a flavouring and aroma hand in this brew. Dry red wine notes abound and this is very unbeer like to me. Certainly not my best beer of the session.

Stumpy little bottle @ Richs 7k tasting. Pours murky reddish amber, thin tan head. Aroma brings a vibrant pinot noir influence. Taste continues, perhaps a little too much. Seems this beer is all about the pinot noir barrel which overshadows the usual eisbock character. Wouldve preferred a more subtle integration.
Bottle shared at MTG III via Beer Gonzo; dark brown pour with a thin tan head, aroma has big red grape action, taste has big red wine, some vanilla, big chocolate.

Ive got a stuffed up head so Im giving it the benefit of the doubt for aroma. Appearances hazy Brown and still. Flavors surprisingly mild multi slightly tart with a little bit of the red wine barrel. Body is ok, some alcoholic warmth. Not much reason to cellar it.

Huge thanks to Gene (Travlr) and Donnie (GenDV138) for helping me to land this rare beer. Bottle looks awesome. Beer in the glass brownish, no head. Intense alcoholic aroma. Starts fiery-alcoholic, sharp, warming. Fruity notes of berries, grapes, light sourish. Shows sides of a good dry red wine. Finish much more balanced, less sharp, some woody-malty notes. Still warming-alcoholic, but not too intense. Warming finish. But quite drinkable for its strength. Definetly a beer to enjoy.
Caramelized malt. Pours amber without much head or lacing. Tangy citrus tinge. Very sweet, some peel. Good balance for style. Bottles hared at tasting.

11.2oz bottle pours a hazy brown with some ringing, beige head. Nose has booze, some odd banana, a little wood, raisin, port. Flavor has pomegranate, acid, oily, vegetal, wet wood, booze, cherry, port. Oily and hot on the finish. Messy.

Bottle at the nuplastikk returns tasting in VA. Clear golden orange with off-white head. Aromas of stone fruit, tropical fruit, apples. Tastes of floral notes, citrus, toast. Medium-light body with a dry finish.
From a 35 cl bottle shared at the 2016 Nuplastik is back tasting. Pours a hazy brown with a scant off white head. Flavors of cherry and toffee. Hides its alcohol well.
Bottle from the Wine Source. Clear brown color, still. Aroma of candied vinous vanilla and caramel. Taste is sweet, boozy bready vinous butterscotch. Nice.
